comments: Theorem: If both numbers q and 2q-1 are primes and n=q*(2q-1) then 6^(n-1)==1 (mod n)(n is in the sequence) iff q is of the form 12k+1. 2701,18721,49141,104653,226801,665281,... are such terms. This sequence is a subsequence of A122783. - _Farideh Firoozbakht_, Sep 12 2006Composite numbers n such that 6^(n-1) == 1 (mod n). [From Michel Lagneau, Feb 18 2012]
references: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, A12.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: R. J. Mathar and T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000 (R. J. Mathar to 118 terms)
Index entries for sequences related to pseudoprimes
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
